metadata.title: The Transformation of the Canadian Domestic Servant, 1871-1931

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change
relevance.relevance: The study examines the decline of domestic service as a paid occupation and its replacement by unpaid housework, driven by technological changes in household management.

design.sample_characteristics: The study focuses on domestic servants in Canada, particularly in urban areas, during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

dependent_variables.displaced: The decline of domestic service as a paid occupation and its replacement by unpaid housework.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: High turnover and short duration of employment in domestic service.
dependent_variables.duration: Short duration of employment in domestic service.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Domestic servants' wages did not keep pace with other occupations, leading to a decline in the occupation.

text_fragments: 'I'd rather pick rags and keep my self-respect!' Such was the reaction of one Canadian woman who faced the prospect of becoming a domestic servant in the early twentieth century.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the transformation of domestic service due to technological changes and changing social dynamics, leading to the decline of the occupation.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Period of economic growth and demographic changes in Canada.
historical_context.institutional_context: The study discusses labor market dynamics and the role of immigration in the labor supply for domestic service.

outcomes.main_findings: The study finds that domestic service declined as a paid occupation due to technological changes and changing social dynamics, leading to its replacement by unpaid housework.
outcomes.conclusions: The decline of domestic service was driven by technological changes and demographic shifts, leading to the transformation of household work.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The decline of paid domestic service led to the rise of unpaid housework, impacting women's roles in society.

quality_assessment.methodological_limitations: The study relies on historical census data, which may have limitations in data quality and representativeness.
quality_assessment.coherence: The study provides a coherent narrative supported by historical data and analysis.
quality_assessment.adequacy_of_data: The study uses comprehensive historical data from Canadian censuses to support its findings.
quality_assessment.relevance: The study is relevant to understanding the impact of technological change on labor displacement in the context of domestic service.
